title: No Code Here Yet
text: I am absolutely looking forward to working with R text, plots and graphs

title: My First Blog. An example from the library Indometh a dataset of the pharmacokinetics of Indomethacin
text:
library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.2.2


── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ──

✔ readr   2.1.3      ✔ forcats 0.5.2

✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

# view some data sets maybe?
#call ggplot
#data() view a list of built-ins
# select Indomethacin pharmacokinetics data data
#view Indometh data set , including variables  to set on x and y axes

?Indometh

starting httpd help server ... done

ggplot(data=Indometh,
        mapping = aes(x= time,
        y= conc ))+
    geom_point()+
    geom_smooth()

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'





In an attempt to learn data analysis the R programming language is mentioned often. Yet it seems to be far less commonly taught than a more prevalent data science language Python.
In this blog entry I will write what my goals are for the next few months of this course.
I would like to spend time on applied data science, such as practical uses for R. The analyses that would be useful when working in a real-world setting and also collaborative benefits of using R versus other languages.
Visualizing data in R , and becoming more comfortable with syntax of a new language are the reasons I decided this course would benefit me.

[1] "one"   "two"   "three" "four"  "five"  "six"

[1] 1 2 3 4 5 6












mean(y)

[1] 3.5





        a. Use frozen butter
        b. Use an oxo good grip pastry blender while cutting fat into the dough
        c. dont rush lamination

Basic Graphs and Plots in R

Dataset gravity

✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()


Warning: package 'boot' was built under R version 4.2.2


   g series
1 76      1
2 82      1
3 83      1
4 54      1
5 35      1
6 46      1








Plotting the Gravity Dataset

The gravity data frame has 81 rows and 2 columns.
“Between May 1934 and July 1935, the National Bureau of Standards in Washington D.C. conducted a series of experiments to estimate the acceleration due to gravity, g, at Washington. Each experiment produced a number of replicate estimates of g using the same methodology. Although the basic method remained the same for all experiments, that of the reversible pendulum, there were changes in configuration.
The gravity data frame contains the data from all eight experiments. The grav data frame contains the data from the experiments 7 and 8. The data are expressed as deviations from 980.000 in centimetres per second squared.”

library(tidyverse)
ggplot(data = gravity) + 
  geom_point(mapping = aes(x = g, y =series))

text:
title: “Data Summaries”
author: ” C Miller”
date: “2023-03-15”
categories: [analysis]
image: “dep_image_troisieme.jpeg”


Data Summaries

My long term project, mental health data


NYS Vtal Health Statistics, Suicide Deaths by Age Group Race


https://health.data.ny.gov/Health/Vital-Statistics-Suicide-Deaths-by-Age-Group-Race-/j6fz-a4ta

library(tidyverse) # readr and tibble

Warning: package 'tidyverse' was built under R version 4.2.2


── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.2 ──
✔ ggplot2 3.4.0      ✔ purrr   1.0.1 
✔ tibble  3.1.8      ✔ dplyr   1.0.10
✔ tidyr   1.3.0      ✔ stringr 1.5.0 
✔ readr   2.1.3      ✔ forcats 0.5.2 


Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.2.2


Warning: package 'tibble' was built under R version 4.2.2


Warning: package 'tidyr' was built under R version 4.2.2


Warning: package 'readr' was built under R version 4.2.2


Warning: package 'purrr' was built under R version 4.2.2


Warning: package 'dplyr' was built under R version 4.2.2


Warning: package 'stringr' was built under R version 4.2.2


Warning: package 'forcats' was built under R version 4.2.2


── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

library(rio) # import/export any data

Warning: package 'rio' was built under R version 4.2.2

library(readxl)

Warning: package 'readxl' was built under R version 4.2.2

nys_suicide <- import("suicide_nys_region_2003.csv")

the_nys_data <-readr::read_csv("suicide_nys_region_2003.csv")

Rows: 2561 Columns: 8
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): Region, RaceorEthnicity, Sex, AgeGroup
dbl (4): Year, FirearmDeaths, Alcohol-Related Deaths, SuicideDeaths

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

glimpse(nys_suicide)

Rows: 2,561
Columns: 8
$ Year                     <int> 2015, 2015, 2015, 2015, 2015, 2015, 2015, 201…
$ Region                   <chr> "NYC", "NYC", "NYC", "NYC", "NYC", "NYC", "NY…
$ RaceorEthnicity          <chr> "Black Non Hispanic", "Black Non Hispanic", "…
$ Sex                      <chr> "F", "M", "F", "M", "F", "M", "F", "M", "F", …
$ AgeGroup                 <chr> "9-Jan", "9-Jan", "19-Oct", "19-Oct", "20-24"…
$ FirearmDeaths            <int> 1, 0, 2, 18, 0, 34, 4, 65, 2, 29, 0, 17, 2, 1…
$ `Alcohol-Related Deaths` <int> 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 10, 4, 9, 20, 34, 73, 58, 1…
$ SuicideDeaths            <int> 0, 0, 1, 4, 3, 9, 5, 20, 4, 6, 8, 16, 2, 4, 0…

spec(the_nys_data) #column data type

cols(
  Year = col_double(),
  Region = col_character(),
  RaceorEthnicity = col_character(),
  Sex = col_character(),
  AgeGroup = col_character(),
  FirearmDeaths = col_double(),
  `Alcohol-Related Deaths` = col_double(),
  SuicideDeaths = col_double()
)

# comparing the three causes of death

mean(nys_suicide$`FirearmDeaths`)

[1] 10.00234

mean(nys_suicide$`Alcohol-Related Deaths`)

[1] 56.44358

mean(nys_suicide$`SuicideDeaths`)

[1] 20.12886




Create a table of mean values of some data

etoh_firearm_suicide <- summarise(nys_suicide,
                                  mean_Alcohol = mean(nys_suicide$`Alcohol-Related Deaths`),
                                  mean_firearm = mean(nys_suicide$FirearmDeaths),
                                  mean_suicide = mean(nys_suicide$SuicideDeaths)
)

etoh_firearm_suicide

  mean_Alcohol mean_firearm mean_suicide
1     56.44358     10.00234     20.12886




Visualize Data


An assisted attempt at barplots

unique(nys_suicide$RaceorEthnicity)

[1] "Black Non Hispanic" "Hispanic"           "Not Stated"        
[4] "Other Non Hispanic" "White Non Hispanic"

ggplot(nys_suicide, aes(x = RaceorEthnicity, y = SuicideDeaths))+
  geom_bar(stat="summary", fun = "mean")



means <- nys_suicide %>%
  group_by(RaceorEthnicity) %>%
 summarize(mean_suicide = mean(SuicideDeaths))

means

# A tibble: 5 × 2
  RaceorEthnicity    mean_suicide
  <chr>                     <dbl>
1 Black Non Hispanic        2.98 
2 Hispanic                 44.4  
3 Not Stated                0.632
4 Other Non Hispanic        3.26 
5 White Non Hispanic       24.3  

ggplot(means, aes(x=RaceorEthnicity, y = mean_suicide)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position ="dodge")



ggplot(means, aes(x=RaceorEthnicity, y = mean_suicide)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity")






View the distribution with geom_point

ggplot(nys_suicide, aes(x = RaceorEthnicity, y = SuicideDeaths))+
  geom_point()
